step1_initial_points.title: Inefficient High-Volume Legal Task Processing
step1_initial_points.description: Lawyers spend significant time on repetitive, manual tasks like summarizing documents, creating chronologies, and initial drafting. This hampers productivity and diverts skilled lawyers from high-value strategic work. AGS needs to automate these workflows to improve efficiency.

step1_initial_points.title: Meeting Strict Government Security Requirements
step1_initial_points.description: As a government legal service, any AI tool must meet stringent security standards, including IRAP certification at the PROTECTED level, Essential Eight compliance, and Australian data sovereignty. Non-compliance is a major risk and a non-negotiable barrier to adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Poor Integration with Existing Core Systems
step1_initial_points.description: New tools must integrate seamlessly with their core legal tech stack (iManage Cloud, Elite 3E, Microsoft Office) to avoid creating data silos and fragmented workflows. They are not looking to replace these systems, so deep integration and API access are critical for adoption.

step1_initial_points.title: Difficulty Finding Internal Knowledge & Precedents
step1_initial_points.description: Existing knowledge bases and document management systems make it hard to find relevant legal opinions, precedents, and internal expertise quickly. This leads to duplicated effort and missed insights. They need to improve search relevance and findability across their internal data.

step1_initial_points.title: Risk of Non-Compliant or Unexplainable AI
step1_initial_points.description: Operating in a government context demands that any AI use is ethical, responsible, transparent, and explainable. Tools must comply with the Australian Privacy Act and Archives Act. 'Black-box' AI solutions present an unacceptable governance and reputational risk.

step1_initial_points.title: Current Tools Lack Advanced Automation
step1_initial_points.description: AGS is looking beyond standard generative AI. They have a strategic interest in emerging 'agentic AI' systems capable of autonomous, multi-step task execution and goal-driven workflows. Current tools may lack the sophistication to handle complex, chained legal processes.

step1_initial_points.title: Inconsistent Work Product Across Large Teams
step1_initial_points.description: With approximately 570 lawyers across multiple offices, ensuring consistent adherence to AGS style guides and quality standards in all communications and documents is a significant operational challenge. They need tools to automate quality control and enforcement.

step1_initial_points.title: Slow and Manual Bid Response Process
step1_initial_points.description: Generating capability statements and summarizing complex tender requirements for bid responses is a time-consuming, manual process. This inefficiency can slow down business development and impact their ability to respond quickly to new government opportunities.

step1_initial_points.title: Lack of Lawyer Capacity Visibility
step1_initial_points.description: AGS needs to efficiently allocate new work by checking lawyer workload against their expertise and leave schedules. Manual processes for this are inefficient and can lead to over or under-utilization of their 570 lawyers, affecting client service and staff wellbeing.

step2_filtered_points.title: Inefficient High-Volume Legal Task Processing
step2_filtered_points.description: Lawyers spend significant time on repetitive, manual tasks like summarizing documents, creating chronologies, and initial drafting. This hampers productivity and diverts skilled lawyers from high-value strategic work. AGS needs to automate these workflows to improve efficiency.

step2_filtered_points.title: Meeting Strict Government Security Requirements
step2_filtered_points.description: As a government legal service, any AI tool must meet stringent security standards, including IRAP certification at the PROTECTED level, Essential Eight compliance, and Australian data sovereignty. Non-compliance is a major risk and a non-negotiable barrier to adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: Poor Integration with Existing Core Systems
step2_filtered_points.description: New tools must integrate seamlessly with their core legal tech stack (iManage Cloud, Elite 3E, Microsoft Office) to avoid creating data silos and fragmented workflows. They are not looking to replace these systems, so deep integration and API access are critical for adoption.

step2_filtered_points.title: Risk of Non-Compliant or Unexplainable AI
step2_filtered_points.description: Operating in a government context demands that any AI use is ethical, responsible, transparent, and explainable. Tools must comply with the Australian Privacy Act and Archives Act. 'Black-box' AI solutions present an unacceptable governance and reputational risk.

step2_filtered_points.title: Difficulty Finding Internal Knowledge & Precedents
step2_filtered_points.description: Existing knowledge bases and document management systems make it hard to find relevant legal opinions, precedents, and internal expertise quickly. This leads to duplicated effort and missed insights. They need to improve search relevance and findability across their internal data.

step2_filtered_points.title: Current Tools Lack Advanced Automation
step2_filtered_points.description: AGS is looking beyond standard generative AI. They have a strategic interest in emerging 'agentic AI' systems capable of autonomous, multi-step task execution and goal-driven workflows. Current tools may lack the sophistication to handle complex, chained legal processes.

step3_refined_points.title: Inefficient & Unadvanced Legal Workflows
step3_refined_points.description: Lawyers are burdened by manual, repetitive tasks, and existing tools lack advanced automation for complex, multi-step processes. This inefficiency diverts skilled lawyers from high-value strategic work, necessitating a solution that can automate both simple and sophisticated legal workflows.

step3_refined_points.title: Strict Government Security & Sovereignty Mandates
step3_refined_points.description: As a government agency, any AI platform must meet non-negotiable technical security standards. This includes IRAP PROTECTED certification, Essential Eight compliance, and Australian data sovereignty. Failure to meet these specific requirements presents a critical risk and is a firm barrier to adoption.

step3_refined_points.title: Fragmented Workflows Due to Poor Integration
step3_refined_points.description: New solutions must deeply integrate with the core legal tech stack (iManage, Elite 3E, MS Office) to prevent data silos and disjointed user experiences. Without seamless API-level integration, any new tool would disrupt established workflows rather than enhance them, hindering adoption.

step3_refined_points.title: Unacceptable AI Governance & Compliance Risk
step3_refined_points.description: The use of 'black-box' AI solutions presents a major governance and reputational risk. Any system must be transparent, explainable, and compliant with Australian law (e.g., Privacy and Archives Acts). An inability to demonstrate responsible and ethical AI use is a non-starter.

step3_refined_points.title: Ineffective Internal Knowledge Discovery
step3_refined_points.description: Valuable legal precedents and internal expertise are buried and difficult to find within existing document management systems. This leads to duplicated research efforts and missed strategic insights. They need to dramatically improve search relevance and findability across internal data.

merge_decisions.merged: Fragmented Workflows Due to Poor Integration
Fragmented Workflows Due to Poor Integration
